My allergies are pretty intense, I take tons of antihistamins and eye drops. I sleep with an air purifier that filters out all the pollen, it's the only way my nose doesn't clog up in the middle of the night and I don't wake up with my eyes so swollen they physically can't open.

I don't want to trivialize "climate change" or the fact the we (humans) have contributed; however, I  don't believe we are headed for a doomsday any time soon as every man-made prediction over the last 50+ years has turned out to be wrong (polar ice gone, oil reserves exhausted, sea levels obliterating coastlines, etc.).  Don't even want to discredit the potential for its effect on allergies.  I do want to postulate another factor - the migration of the population into new/different climates with new/different allergens.  The recent census confirms that many people are moving to Texas, Florida, Idaho et al.  It takes time for the body to adjust to new allergens.   When I moved to Texas in the late 90s the mountain cedar used to absolutely floor me and I was dependent on allergy meds to get through it.  Now I take zero allergy meds and have only mild symptoms during cedar season.  Every body reacts differently, give it time to adjust, the human body is incredibly adaptable.

Australia has a phenomenon called Thunderstorm Asthma and the government sends out health alerts when it is forecast by the Bureau of Meteorology. Essentially its when a storm comes through after a particularly hot dry windy day during spring. The sudden humidity rise causes pollen grains to explode, resulting in a magnified allergenic response. A number of people died a few years ago after a significant event, which pushed the ambulance system past breaking point without warning.
On the bright side, though, 0 people have contracted the flu this year. /eyeroll

There's also an interesting theory about the intentional planting of trees in urban and suburban areas -- almost exclusively male trees, to avoid the mess of rotting fruit. According to the theory, this has been going on so long (decades) and is so widespread that all these male trees have been evolving to produce more pollen as they compete for relatively scarcer female trees. We've put much of this pollen in the air by favoring the male plants that produce it.

Additionally, humans are planting many more trees in populated areas, including non-native exotic tree species. This means that people are being exposed to a greater quantity and variety of pollen.
